GUIDE.title: C++ Style Guide for Endless Sky

CATEGORY.title: Background
CATEGORY.p: Each section of this style guide can be read as a "how to": how to create source code files, how to create classes, etc. The sections are ordered hierarchically, from biggest "units" (files, namespaces, classes) to increasingly smaller ones (variables, comments, formatting). Our style choices are based on a small set of principles:

ul.li: Readability is achieved by laying out text in a clear visual hierarchy.
Code should not rely on features of a particular editor or compiler.
Formatting should be consistent to avoid confusing or distracting the reader.
Reducing the risk of bugs is important even if it takes more work.

CATEGORY.title: Files
CATEGORY.p: This section deals with naming and encoding of source code files and the items that appear at the start of each file.

STYLEPOINT.title: Line endings
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: All files should have Unix-style line endings.

BODY.p: That is, "\n" alone, not "\r\n" (Windows style). If an editor changes Unix line endings to Windows style, this causes issues with source control diffs because those lines appear to be changed even though their actual text is the same.

STYLEPOINT.title: File encodings
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: All files should be plain ASCII.

BODY.p: That is, nothing beyond the 127-character ASCII set should be used. This is to ensure maximum cross-compatibility.

STYLEPOINT.title: File extensions
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: All C++ files should use ".h" and ".cpp" for their extensions.

BODY.p: This is a somewhat arbitrary choice, but these seem to be the most commonly used extensions.

STYLEPOINT.title: One class per file
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Each class "MyClass" should have its own .h and .cpp files, and they should be named "MyClass.h" and "MyClass.cpp".

BODY.p: This is so that it is easy to find the implementation of any class you are interested in.

STYLEPOINT.title: Names for files with no classes
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: If a file does not contain any classes (such as "main.cpp" or "shift.h"), its name should be lower-case.

BODY.p: This is just to make it clear that the file is not defining a class.

STYLEPOINT.title: Header file guards
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: All header files should have #define guards, and they should be in the format "#ifndef MY_CLASS_H_".

BODY.p: The C++ standard technically does not allow source code files to define macros that start with an underscore or contain a double underscore.

STYLEPOINT.title: Header and copyright statement
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY:
Each file should begin with a header which specifies the file name, copyright, and licensing information, e.g.:
/* Key.h Copyright (c) 2014 by Michael Zahniser
Endless Sky is free software: you can redistribute it and/or modify it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by the Free Software Foundation, either version 3 of the License, or (at your option) any later version.
Endless Sky is distributed in the hope that it will be useful, but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE. See the GNU General Public License for more details. */

BODY.p: If you make substantial additions or changes to a file, please add your name to the copyright list.

STYLEPOINT.title: Placement of #includes
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: All #includes in a file should be placed prior to anything else except for the #ifndef guards.

BODY.p: This is so it is immediately clear which files a given file includes.

STYLEPOINT.title: Order of #includes in a .h file
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY:
Within a .h file, the #includes should be broken into "paragraphs" each separated by a single blank line:
Classes that this file's class inherits from.
Other files in the "endless-sky" code base.
Non-standard third-party libraries.
Standard libraries.
Optionally, forward declarations of anything that can be forward-declared.

It is helpful but not required to alphabetize the lines within each "paragraph" of #includes.

Forward-declaring classes instead of #including their headers reduces compilation time somewhat because it eliminates dependencies. But, compilation times are so short for this project anyways that using forward declarations is not an absolute requirement.

STYLEPOINT.title: Order of #includes in a .cpp file
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY:
Within a .cpp file, the #includes should be broken into "paragraphs" each separated by a single blank line:
This file's corresponding .h.
Other files in the "endless-sky" code base.
Non-standard third-party libraries.
Standard libraries.

BODY.p: For example, a .cpp file might contain the following #includes:
It is helpful but not required to alphabetize the lines within each "paragraph" of #includes.

CATEGORY.title: Namespaces
CATEGORY.p: This is not a large enough project to require splitting it into multiple namespaces.

STYLEPOINT.title: Use the global namespace
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Put all classes except for local helpers in the global namespace.

BODY.p: This project is never going to grow to a size where multiple namespaces are needed.

STYLEPOINT.title: Unnamed namespaces
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Put local helper classes, functions, and variables in an unnamed namespace.

BODY.p: This allows you to define static classes, functions, and variables that are guaranteed to only be visible from within a single compilation unit. (You should not be using globals that are visible from more than one .cpp!)

STYLEPOINT.title: Using declarations
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Do not put any using declarations in any header file.

BODY.p: This is so that a file cannot end up dependent on a using declaration provided by a file that it #includes and suddenly failing to compile if that other file changes.
This includes general using-directives (e.g. "using namespace std;") in addition to specific using-declarations (e.g. "using std::string;").

STYLEPOINT.title: The std namespace
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Each .cpp file should put "using namespace std;" immediately after the #includes.

BODY.p: Because our class and function names are capitalized, there is no risk of name collision, and it is simply cleaner to not have to use the std:: prefix everywhere.

CATEGORY.title: Classes
CATEGORY.p: For clarity and simplicity, nearly every function should be part of a class, and every class should be contained in its own files named after that class.

STYLEPOINT.title: Class names
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Class names should be CapitalizedCamelCase. Do not use Hungarian notation.

BODY.p: That is, for example, do not put a "C" at the start of all your class names to mark the fact that they are classes. Since we do not define any global functions, a capitalized name by itself is pretty much guaranteed to be a class, so we do not need any further markers to help the reader.

STYLEPOINT.title: Order of declarations
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY:
A class definition should contain the following sections (most of which will be omitted for most classes) in this order, with each section introduced by a "public:", "protected:", or "private:" marker:
public enums and nested classes
public static constants
public static functions
public functions
protected functions
private nested classes
private functions
private variables

BODY.p: Anything not listed here (e.g. public non-constant variables, protected variables, etc.) should not be used.
Here is an example class definition, with extra comments added to point out aspects of the formatting:

STYLEPOINT.title: Inline functions
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Do not define any functions within the class definition.

BODY.p: The class definition should provide a concise definition of the interface of the class, so that someone using the class can scan through it quickly. Defining functions inline makes this more difficult.
If you have determined that making a function inline will substantially improve performance, or if it is a templated function, define it in the header after the end of the class definition.

STYLEPOINT.title: Initialization order
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Initializer lists in constructors should list the variables in the same order they occur in the class.

BODY.p: Variables are initialized in the order they occur in the class definition, not in the initializer list. Most compilers will report a warning if you change the order because it means your initializer list might be written to depend on a variable that has not been initialized yet.

STYLEPOINT.title: Explicit constructors
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Constructors with only one argument should be labeled "explicit".

BODY.p: This is to avoid defining implicit type conversions that might then be used by the compiler in surprising ways.

STYLEPOINT.title: Operator overloading
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Use operator overloading only if implementing an arithmetic class and only if the operator has its well-established mathematical sense.

BODY.p: For example, the "Point" class can define Point + Point, Point * scalar, etc., but it should not define Point * Point because it is ambiguous whether that should be an element-by-element product, a dot product, or a cross product.

STYLEPOINT.title: Use of class vs. struct
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Do not use the "struct" keyword; just define a class with public data members instead.

BODY.p: Exception: occasionally when using the POSIX libraries you need the "struct" keyword to define that a typename is a struct and not a function of the same name, e.g.:

STYLEPOINT.title: Inheritance
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Use inheritance only for an "is a" relationship. Do not use protected or private inheritance.

BODY.p: Use composition if MyClass "has" an OtherClass instead of "is" an OtherClass.

STYLEPOINT.title: Public data members
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Avoid public non-constant data members except in classes that are used like structs.

BODY.p: Occasional exceptions are allowed if they lead to much clearer code.

STYLEPOINT.title: Mutable
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Use "mutable" only for class members not related to the outwardly visible state of the class.

BODY.p: For example, if a class caches the result of a complex calculation, that may be stored in a mutable variable. Similarly, if a class owns a worker thread that it communicates with, a const function checking on the worker's status may need to use a mutable mutex.

STYLEPOINT.title: Nested classes
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Nested classes are allowed, but use them sparingly.

BODY.p: For example, a nested class representing a single node of a data structure or a complex return type might make sense.

STYLEPOINT.title: Runtime type information
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Do not make use of runtime type information.

BODY.p: That includes using dynamic_cast<>().

STYLEPOINT.title: Friends
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Use friends only when absolutely necessary.

BODY.p: Using friends is better than making private class data public just so that one other class can use it, but much worse than just refactoring to avoid the need for data sharing in the first place.

STYLEPOINT.title: Reinventing the wheel
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Do not create your own classes where you can just use the STL.

BODY.p: The STL will generally be as fast as anything you can write yourself, and also much less buggy.

CATEGORY.title: Functions
CATEGORY.p: This section describes how functions should be named and also lays out some widely-accepted design principles for factoring code into functions.

STYLEPOINT.title: Function names
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Function names should be CapitalizedCamelCase

BODY.p: There is no single standard in C++ for whether or not function names are capitalized. But, constructor names must be capitalized, so it makes sense to capitalize the others too. Also, it is easy to distinguish class names from function names or variables based solely on context, but the only easy way to distinguish a function from a function object is by capitalization.
Exception: function names that match the standard library (such as begin() and end()) may be lower-case.

STYLEPOINT.title: Definition order
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Functions in the .cpp file should appear in the same order as they are declared in the .h file.

BODY.p: This makes it easier to scan through the files to find a function, which is often faster than going to the trouble of doing a Find... within the file. It also means that related functions are grouped together instead of appearing in an arbitrary order.

STYLEPOINT.title: Const correctness
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Any function or function parameter that can be const, should be const.

BODY.p: It takes a little bit of extra work when defining a class interface, but makes all sorts of subtle errors impossible to commit.
Note that this means that if a class provides begin() and end() iterators, you need to define both a const and a non-const copy of those functions.

STYLEPOINT.title: Exception safety
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Use the RAII idiom whenever possible so that code is automatically exception-safe.

BODY.p: That is, use objects like ofstream, vector, lock_guard, etc. that automatically do whatever cleanup is necessary (closing a file, freeing memory, releasing a mutex) when they are destroyed. That produces cleaner code anyways, and has the advantage that you don't even have to worry about where in the function an exception might get thrown.

STYLEPOINT.title: Avoid copy-and-pasted code
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: If nearly identical code appears in two places, factor it out into a separate function.

BODY.p: Otherwise, if you make a change or a bug fix, you're likely to make it in one of the copies but not in the other. And, copy-and-paste is often a sign of quickly written throw-away code.

STYLEPOINT.title: Non-member functions
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: All functions should either be a member of a class or of an unnamed namespace.

BODY.p: This implies that some classes may consist entirely of static functions, and never actually be intended to be instantiated.

This is so that it is immediately clear to anyone reading the code what file they need to look at to see the declaration or definition of that function. That is, if I see "MyClass::DoStuff(myData);", I know to look at MyClass.h for details. If I see "DoStuff(myData);", I have to read through all the #includes to see which one defined DoStuff().
Functions in an unnamed namespace are only visible in a single .cpp file, so they will generally just be helper functions for that particular class.

STYLEPOINT.title: Void
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Do not use "void" to denote a function with no arguments.

BODY.p: An empty list of arguments is much clearer than a list of one element that happens to be void. The only reason people use "void" is as a carry-over from C, where these two function declarations mean different things:
BODY.CODE_SNIPPET: void F(void); // has zero arguments. void F(); // has an undefined number of arguments.

STYLEPOINT.title: Default arguments
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Use default arguments only when it is self-evident what the default ought to be.

BODY.p: Using default arguments is preferable to defining several overloads of a function which all duplicate the same code.

CATEGORY.title: Variables
CATEGORY.p: This section deals with naming of variables, scoping, initialization, etc.

STYLEPOINT.title: Lower-case camelCase
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Variable names should be in camelCase, starting with a lower-case letter.

BODY.p: This is so that variables can be easily distinguished from class and function names.

STYLEPOINT.title: Constants in ALL_CAPS
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Constants may be in ALL_CAPITALS_WITH_UNDERSCORES.

BODY.p: Or they can use the same format as normal variables.

STYLEPOINT.title: Use const rather than #define
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Constants should be defined as "static const" rather than using macros.

BODY.p: This avoids unintended side effects and is also more efficient if the variable in question has a non-trivial constructor, because this way one instance of it can be reused.

STYLEPOINT.title: No Hungarian notation
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Do not use Hungarian notation (prefixes or suffixes on variable names just to represent their type).

BODY.p: Hungarian notation makes variable names harder to read and harder to remember, because instead of English words they include random character sequences like "lptsz". Also, because the compiler is checking for type safety anyways, these prefixes do nothing to improve code quality.

This also includes not putting "m_" or "_" before or after member variable names. If your functions and classes are well-factored, you should not encounter many situations where it is unclear to a reader whether a variable is a local variable or a member variable.

STYLEPOINT.title: Point of first use
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Declare variables at the point of first use, not at the top of the function.

BODY.p: This avoids having variables be declared but not yet initialized. It also avoids requiring someone who is reading the middle of a function to keep looking back to the start of the function to figure out what variables are.

STYLEPOINT.title: Avoid reusing variables
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Rather than using one vaguely named temporary variable in many places in a function, just define new variables for each new value you are storing.

BODY.p: The compiler will be able to figure out when each variable is no longer in use and can reuse whatever register it is in; you don not have to manage that.

STYLEPOINT.title: Smallest possible scope
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Put local variables in the smallest scope possible.

BODY.p: This goes along with the previous two points, and also helps avoid name collisions. It is also sometimes useful to define a scope purely for the sake of limiting a variable's lifetime:

STYLEPOINT.title: No globals
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Use a Singleton class or a similar construct instead of global variables.

BODY.p: A Singleton is almost as dangerous as a global, but has the advantage that it is easy to see when it is being used.

STYLEPOINT.title: Be careful with static locals
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Do not use static local variables unless you have thought through the thread safety implications.

BODY.p: A static local is initialized the first time the flow of control passes through a function, so if two threads call the same function at the same time, it can be initialized twice. Use a static variable in an anonymous namespace instead, to be safe.

CATEGORY.title: Comments
CATEGORY.p: Exceedingly verbose comments can be as harmful as no comments at all; this section provides some guidelines for finding a happy medium.

STYLEPOINT.title: Headers are for quick reference
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: As a general principle, the header file for a class should be usable as a quick reference to that classes interface.

BODY.p: That is, someone who needs to use a class but does not need to know implementation details should be able to get all the information that they need from the header. This also implies that you should not put implementation details or other excess comments into the header, since it should be as concise as possible. In particular, it is not required to have individual comments for every function and variable in the header.

STYLEPOINT.title: Comments should not reiterate code
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Comments should provide additional information needed to interpret the code, rather than reiterating every step the code performs.

BODY.p: That is, avoid this sort of thing:
BODY.BAD_CODE_SNIPPET: int temp; // Define an integer called "temp". temp = y; // Copy "y" into "temp". y = x; // Copy "x" into "y". x = temp; // Copy the previous value of "y" into "x".

Of course, in this case using std::swap() is a better alternative than either.

STYLEPOINT.title: Comment paragraphs, not lines
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Put comments at the start of each non-trivial code paragraph explaining what it does.

BODY.p: That is, by scanning through the comments, someone should be able to get an outline of what a function does. This also means that clarity is improved by taking out comments that are too low-level, as in the first example in the previous point.

STYLEPOINT.title: Comments for classes
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Put comments before each class definition giving an overview of the class.

BODY.p: The overview should explain where and why you would use a class; comments on the individual functions will explain how.

STYLEPOINT.title: Dead code
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Do not leave any "dead code" when checking code in.

BODY.p: This does not include code-like comments, e.g. equations.

STYLEPOINT.title: Multi-line comments
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Multi-line comments should only be used for the copyright header.

BODY.p: This is mainly so that multi-line comments can be used as a quick and dirty way to comment out blocks of code while developing, but it also makes it much easier to write automated programs that extract all the comment text, e.g. for spell checking the comments.

STYLEPOINT.title: Decorations
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Fancy, decorated comments should not be used.

BODY.p: For example, perhaps your editor has a "feature" that lets you automatically insert comments like this:
BODY.BAD_CODE_SNIPPET: /************************************* * My fancy comment. * This is a comment that could have * been a single line without these * fancy decorative elements. *************************************/
BODY.p: But, those two lines of asterisks are eye-grabbing and completely unnecessary on any editor that supports syntax coloring, and more importantly anyone using a different editor would have to manually type an asterisk at the beginning of every comment line and figure out exactly how many asterisks are in those rows at the top and bottom, in order to be consistent with your code.

STYLEPOINT.title: SVN commit comments
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: When committing code to SVN, include comments describing everything that is changing.

BODY.p: If you are committing multiple changes, it is best to group them into separate commits that each change one thing, rather than committing them all together.

CATEGORY.title: Formatting
CATEGORY.p: Proper formatting creates a visual hierarchy, e.g. of a set of functions (each separated by large vertical gaps) composed of a set of code paragraphs (separated by small vertical gaps) each composed of lines, which are composed of individual words (separated by horizontal space). If any of that white space is left out, objects in the hierarchy merge together and readability is harmed. Also, if code is inconsistently formatted it can be confusing and distracting, and looks sloppy and unprofessional.

STYLEPOINT.title: Tabs
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Use tabs instead of spaces so that the code can be edited in any editor easily.

BODY.p: Some editors support "smart spaces" where pressing TAB inserts some number of spaces and pressing DELETE deletes the proper number of spaces if there is nothing before the cursor on the previous line but white space, but most do not, requiring you to press DELETE exactly the right number of times to get to your desired indentation level.

STYLEPOINT.title: Line length
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Try to keep lines to about 80 characters in length, and wrap anything over 120 characters.

BODY.p: Keeping the code all on one line is preferable in most cases, even if you have to rewrite the line into two separate statements to make it short enough. Wrapped lines are hard to read, but so are super-long lines.

STYLEPOINT.title: Large vertical breaks
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Put three blank lines between function definitions, and before and after the class definition in a .h file.

BODY.p: Aside from files themselves, these are the largest "units" the code is broken up into. If your code is well-written, the reader should not need to keep looking back and forth between multiple functions, so it does not matter that the extra space will make it so fewer functions fit on the screen at once.

STYLEPOINT.title: Medium vertical breaks
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Put two blank lines between sections in a class definition, or to split up sections of code paragraphs in a large function.

BODY.p: Of course, if a function is that long it might need to be refactored anyways.

STYLEPOINT.title: Small vertical breaks
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Use single blank lines to group lines of code into "paragraphs," both within class definitions and within functions.

BODY.p: The rules here are analogous to paragraphs in prose: start with an introductory sentence (e.g. a comment summarizing what follows) and make sure that each "paragraph" is only dealing with one thing.

STYLEPOINT.title: One expression per line
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Do not put multiple expression on the same line.

BODY.p: Except, of course, for the three individual clauses contained in a for loop.

STYLEPOINT.title: Parentheses
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Do not put a space before or after the parentheses for functions and control statements.

BODY.p: There is no consensus on this among programmers. But, the mathematical convention is to never put a space, i.e. you never write "sin (x)". Much of our code is mathematical in nature, so it makes sense to follow that convention.

If you are used to putting spaces before the parentheses, rather than trying to adjust your typing you might find it easier to just do a find/replace before committing your code, e.g. replacing "if (" with "if(", etc. You can also grep the svn diff of your changes for "^+.*\ (" to check if you missed anything.

STYLEPOINT.title: Return is not a function
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: The "return" keyword does not require parentheses; use them only when what follows is a complex statement, and put a space after "return" in that case.

STYLEPOINT.title: Loop bodies go on a separate line
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Always put the body of an if or loop on a separate line.

BODY.p: That makes debugging easier, and also makes the code easier to read.

STYLEPOINT.title: Use continue rather than empty loop bodies
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: If defining a loop with an empty body, put "continue;" as its body.

STYLEPOINT.title: Const
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Write "const int x", not "int const x".

BODY.p: This just makes more sense in English usage.

STYLEPOINT.title: Pointers and references
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: The & or * when defining a variable should be adjacent to the variable name, not the type.

BODY.p: This is mainly as a reminder that "const int *x" means that *x is a const int, not that x is a "const int*". It also avoids problems like this:
BODY.BAD_CODE_SNIPPET: int* x, y; // x is a pointer, but y is an int! Probably not what you intended.

STYLEPOINT.title: Unary operators
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Do not put spaces between unary operators and their operands.

STYLEPOINT.title: Commas
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Put a space after commas.

BODY.p: This makes lists easier to read.

STYLEPOINT.title: Binary operators
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Put a space before and after all binary operators except for ",", ".", "::", and "->"

BODY.p: This is for readability, so that the things being operated on are visually parsed as separate words.

STYLEPOINT.title: Ternary operators
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Put a space before and after "?" and ":".

BODY.p: This is the same as for binary operators.

CATEGORY.title: Best practices
CATEGORY.p: This section deals with other "best practices" that do not fit cleanly into one of the categories above.

STYLEPOINT.title: Learn new things
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: If you encounter something (a mathematical concept, a syntactical construct, etc.) that you do not understand, use the Internet to learn how it works.

BODY.p: Consider the difference between the "Basic English Wikipedia" and the ordinary English Wikipedia. The former uses much simpler grammar and a much more limited vocabulary... and because of that is wordy, unclear, and ambiguous. A non-native English speaker would prefer the Basic English, but a native speaker will find the "Basic" English harder to read and more time-consuming to comprehend. The same is true in software: using more complex syntax and a wider variety of libraries can, if done well, produce code that is less buggy and easier for an experienced program to read.

For example, an affine transform takes one line to write out in matrix form, or half a page of equations if you are not using linear algebra. In general, when writing code you should assume that anyone reading it has at least a high school level of mathematical ability, so matrix equations, logarithms, trigonometry, calculus, etc. are all fair game.

STYLEPOINT.title: No compiler warnings
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Code should compile with -Wall without any warnings.

BODY.p: Some of the warning are rather pedantic, but the effort required to eliminate them is worth it compared to the effort of tracking down subtle bugs that might otherwise exist.

The "comparing signed to unsigned value" warning is particularly common, since the sizes of STL containers are unsigned, but it's common practice to use plain old "int" whenever an integer is needed, instead of using "unsigned". STYLEPOINT.title: C-style typecasts
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Do not use C-style typecasts.

BODY.p: That is, use static_cast<>() or reinterpret_cast<>(). Try to avoid using dynamic_cast<>() or const_cast<>().

STYLEPOINT.title: Pointers vs. references
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: In function parameters, it may be helpful to pass constant parameters by reference, and non-constant parameters by pointer, so that it is immediately clear which parameters are being modified.

BODY.p: The current code does not do this, but it seems like a good practice to move towards.

STYLEPOINT.title: No manual memory management
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: If at all possible, use wrapper classes instead of explicitly allocating or freeing memory.

BODY.p: This makes code exception-safe, and also avoids all sorts of memory management errors. Note that std::vector always stores its contents in a contiguous block of memory, which you can access with its data() function, so there is almost never any reason to allocate your own memory instead of using vector.

If you must use explicit memory management, always use the C++ keywords "new" and "delete", rather than the C-style malloc() and free() functions. This is because creating memory with one set of functions and deleting it with the other results in undefined behavior. Also, unlike malloc(), "new" ensures that an object is properly constructed.

STYLEPOINT.title: No assumptions about variable sizes
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Do not assume that sizeof(int) or sizeof(void *) will be a certain value.

BODY.p: Use explicit types like int64_t when necessary, or just use a "long long" if all you care about is that a variable is at least 64 bits, not exactly 64 bits.

CATEGORY.title: C++11
CATEGORY.p: C++11 brings substantial additions to the C++ language; in fact, one of the main reasons I started this project was to have an opportunity to see what it is like to design a large project from the ground up using the new features of C++11.

STYLEPOINT.title: nullptr
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Use "nullptr" for pointers rather than "NULL" or "0".

BODY.p: This has clear type-safety benefits, and also avoids needing to use a macro.

STYLEPOINT.title: auto
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Use "auto" only for variables with a very small scope, and only when writing out the full type name would make the code less readable.

BODY.p: That is, do not use "auto" just to save yourself some typing. Code is written once, but read many times, and in general it is going to be helpful to have type names spelled out.

STYLEPOINT.title: Range-based for
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Prefer range-based for loops whenever possible.

BODY.p: Range-based for is more clear and concise than using an index or an iterator.

STYLEPOINT.title: Default assignment and constructors
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Use the "= delete" syntax to disable copying of a class if necessary.

BODY.p: In general, just let the compiler automatically generate the copy constructor and assignment operator; very few classes will require custom copying.

STYLEPOINT.title: Lambdas
STYLEPOINT.SUMMARY: Lambdas are an acceptable alternative to simple function objects.

BODY.p: In particular, use lambdas when working with STL functions that require a function object, because defining the function immediately before using it is clearer than defining it in a class in, say, an anonymous namespace at the top of the file.
